div.p:
A happy new year to you my dear Mrs.
Wedgewood Wedgwood
-- to you and yours -- & as a new years gift I have written to Miles
our bookseller to desire that he would forward
before it is published a set of the new Early Les
sons Lessons for your little people. I am anxious to
offer you as soon as possible this proof that
your maternal praise and your maternal
eagerness to have more of what you flattered
us had been useful to your children & real
ly really operated upon us as a strong motive
The continuation of
Rosamond
was begun the day after we reached home
-- I was diverted by your little girls hope
that "it would not be just the same thing
over again". I trust you will find that it
is not -- but I rather fear that
as these
lessons are two or three a steps higher than
the last she will complain of their being
too difficult - and that she will say to>
me as one of the little Pakenhams once said
"Maria E why did you write Rosamond so difficult?"--
Pray if you ever read prefaces, read my
fathers warning preface to these Early Lessons
& keep back the continuation of Harry and Lucy
from your little ones till they are able to
understand it -- It is quite true that each
Experiment mentioned was tried before
the children of this family & none were
inserted that were not completely understood

Will you desire my friend in London
to call for these tiny volumes as perhaps Miles
may scruple to send these to you by the
coach & at the same time he will deliver
to your friend a copy of the second Edition
of Professional Education which I wish you
would
present with my respects to
Sir James
McIntosh McIntosh
. I am particularly an
-xious anxious that he should see the second edition
of this book because three chapters of it were
entirely rewritten & I hope improved - Sir
James McIntosh gratified us highly when
were in London by what he said of the first
book which he told us he had seen in India - and I cannot
help wishing that if he allows it a place in
his library it should at leastbe in its least
imperfect state - Indeed it is presuming
a great deal to hope that one whose mind
is so full & whose time is so incessantly
occupied with objects of the first magnitude
should ever recur to a book like this which
after it had once been read & judged - But
I think perhaps your friendly care may
find some happy moment when to put it
into his hands open at the chapter
Educa-
tion Education of men intended for public life - this &
the first two chapters in the book on the ques
tion question of genius are those which were rewrit-
ten rewritten & to which I wish to direct his attention

Bernadette's letter to Baron Caderhead
his son's preceptor which we have just
read in to day's paper recalled Prof Ed n
to my mind - as there are so many sen
timents sentiments in which my father has the
honor -- & a real honor it is, to agree with
this great Prince & wise father -- I wish
that Sir James Mc had reviewed
Professional Education instead of Sidney Smith
who in truth did not review it in the least
but merely gave the poor book a cut or two
& then went on retailing in an essay of his
own all that my father had said on Classical
literature - Did you ever see this epigram?
"Sidney Smith, who reviews by abusing & lying
"Says this work is n't not worth either borrowing or buying
"But the world buys the book & finds out to his sorrow
"That he's eager to steal what he scruples to borrow

Now We did not & do not want the
book to be praised beyond its deserts or puffed
in any way - but fairly criticised - Then
we should have profited by its faults
& certainly should have endeavored to rec
tify rectify
them - But we have never had & unless
there should be a new Review of a second
edition never can have this fair opportu
nity opportunity of shewing candor & deference for
just criticism - If Sir James has any fair
opportunity of expressing his sentiments on
any parts of this book, particularly on those
which have been rewritten I do not scruple
to ask him in direct terms to do so - not as
a favor - but as an act of justice; in which
I think he would take pride & pleasure
-- Give my love to your happy family &
be assured that if ever we come to England
again we shall visit you & we trust that
if any of your family come to Ireland they will carry on the old family & friendship
My father & Mrs. Edgeworth & Sneyd join
in all I say - Sneyd is as happy as man can be with his
bride - I should say with his wife - for the
wife is dearer than the bride -
